Amir Kapoor is the protagonist of the play.
He works as a successful lawyer together with Jory.
AmirsAmir's parents emigrated from Pakistan to America and leaded him a clearly point of view against the jewishJewish religion and jewishJewish people.
His mother was extremely islamisticIslamistic and teached her son very early how to deal with jewishJewish people.
In America, Amir changed his name to an indianIndian because of the huge kind of islamophobia in this country in cause of the terrorism act 9/11.
Now he is completely anti-Islamic and married to a white woman, who loves the islamicIslamic culture.
The whole scene could be lead back on this.
Emily and Isaac are partners at work.
She is an artist and he is an art curator.

Just right after Jory and Amir left to buy champagne Isaac tries to kiss her multiple times, tells her Em, I'm in love with you (p. 71, l. 11) and tries to kiss her again - now with no moves against it.
Amir and Jory are working together in a council.
Right before Jory and Isaac arrived this evening, Amir had a talk to his chefs because of his origin.
He works much longer for this council as Jory does so he is pretty sad, when Jory tells him, that they want to make her as a partner of them.
The whole scene three discribesdescribes AmirsAmir's anger and vicious reactions on little things like a racist problem with a waite to beginnbegin of the play or things, Isaac says about him.
This all leads us to the twist-point of AmirsAmir's emotions, where he starts to explode (p. 72, ll. 21-40).
Amir talks to Jory, using many rethoricalrhetorical questions and seems very aggressive.
At the end of his monologue, he uses the word nigger two times (l. 23) as a representation of a victim in the situation.
This describes the given kind of racist using words in the whole dialogue.
In the end of the twist-point scene I just mentioned, it comes to its highlight, where Amir spits into IsaacsIsaac's face (p. 72, l. 40).
This was the first act of violence in this scene.
To spit in someonessomeone elseselse's face is not just disgusting.
It is pretty much humiliating and expressexpresses many emotions.
The following beat is also very a meaningful beat.
It shows the silence after something pretty bad that just happendhappened.
It feels like this is a pretty loud scene and pause between the actions.
It follows another racist and by Isaac.
But not a violential act, more a verbal act.
He says: There's a reason they call you people animals (l. 1, p. 73).
Amir does not respond to that.
Maybe because he does not know what he havehas said everything he wanted to already.
There were no other reactions to AmirsAmir's spit which leads me to think, that they all were massively shokedshocked.
To spit in IsaacsIsaac's face must have meant more to Amir because of his childhood, where his mother spat in AmirsAmir's face because of staying in contact with a jewishJewish girl.
He was raised like that and did it now again to another jewishJewish person.
Another interestinteresting aspect is, that it seemed before like Amir does not really care about the thing between Emily and Isaac, because he just mentioned it just once (ll. 18-19, p. 72).
But when they are alone again, Amir starts to ask her, if she sleeps with him (l. 27).
That shows, that he had it all the time in mind and that he does care about it.
The pause and following beat after the question, seemesseems like she was not sure, but then she answers by shaking her head.
Her following sentences leads to think, that she is not unsure about that, but more about the way she tells Amir that she had an affair and cheated on him.
Amir does not say a word and Emily does not even speak it out loud.
That shows EmilysEmily's kind of ashameness and maybe afraidness against the uncontroleduncontrolled man in front of her.
The fact that she tells Amir could be seen as an act of honistyhonesty, or as a way and a reason out of the relationship.
AmirsAmir's reaction is the turning point of the whole play.
He starts hitting Emily in her face, till he recognizes what he did.
The way of his recognization shows the act of uncontrolleness.
His words Oh, my God... describes his kind of shockness and afraidness of himself.
After he busted all out of his anger by hitting his wife, it is a completely twist of the way you look and Amir and the book.
A few pages before (already in scene three), Amir talked about the Quran and that you were allowed to hit your wife to show that the Men are in charge of women... (p. 64, ll. 12-17).
The following income of the nephew Abe and his silence looks at Emily and then at Amir (ll. 20-24) symolisessymbolizes the hardness of the act that they are not even ready to speak about it.
All in all I have to recognize my thesis of the scene three as a turning point and the final outburst of Amir as correct.
Amir always showed his emotions but in a verbal way.
his violential and brutal actness is very extreme and the way of hitting his wife that harsh could be seen as a twist-point and maybe a comeback of his kind of raised and to get back to the religion.
